At that time, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva Supreme Virtuous King of Universal Illumination addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

This meaning is not so.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Why is it so?
When the TathÄgata first expounded the Nirvana Sutra, he spoke of three kinds:
First, if a patient obtains good medicine, medical treatment, and a nurse, the illness will be easily cured, but if they cannot be obtained, it will be incurable;

Third, whether obtained or not, it can be cured.ğŸ”½All sentient beings are also like this. If they encounter good friends, Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and hear the wonderful Dharma, they can give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment. If they do not encounter [them], they will not be able to give rise to it. This refers to Stream-Enterers, Once-Returners, Non-Returners, Arhats, and Pratyekabuddhas.

Second, even if they encounter good friends, Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, and hear the wonderful Dharma, they still cannot give rise to [the mind of enlightenment]. If they do not encounter [them], they also cannot give rise to it. This refers to the icchantikas.
Third, whether they encounter or do not encounter, all are able to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, namely bodhisattvas.

If it is said that whether they encounter or do not encounter, all give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, then why does the TathÄgata now say that it is due to praising the Buddha-nature that causes sentient beings to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment?
World-Honored One!

If it is said that whether they encounter good friends, buddhas, bodhisattvas, hear the wonderful Dharma, or do not encounter, they are all unable to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, one should know that this meaning is also not so.
Why is it so?
Because such people will attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Because even icchantikas, due to their Buddha-nature, whether they hear it or not, will all attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha said, what is called icchantika?
It means cutting off the roots of goodness.
This meaning is also not so.
Why is it so?
Because the Buddha-nature is not cut off, this Buddha-nature is not subject to cutting off.
How does the Buddha say to cut off all the roots of goodness?
As the Buddha said in the past in the twelve divisions of the scriptures, goodness is of two kinds:
One is permanent, the other impermanent.
The permanent is not cut off, the impermanent is cut off.
Because the impermanent can be cut off, one falls into hell;
The permanent cannot be cut off, why is it not blocked?
The Buddha-nature is not cut off, not an icchantika. Why did the Tathagata say that the icchantika?
World-Honored One!
If because of the Buddha-nature one gives rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment, why did the Tathagata extensively expound the twelve divisions of the scriptures for sentient beings?
World-Honored One!
It is like the four rivers issuing from Lake Anavatapta.
If there are gods, humans, or buddhas who say:
'This river does not enter the great ocean, but returns to its source,'
this is impossible.
The mind of enlightenment is also like this.

Those who have buddha-nature, whether they hear it or not, whether they observe precepts or not, whether they give or not, whether they cultivate or not, whether they have wisdom or not, will all attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
World-Honored One!
Like the Yugamdhara mountain, the sun rises from it and reaches the south.
If the sun thinks:
'I will not go to the west, but return to the east,'
this is impossible.

Buddha-nature is also like this. If one does not hear it, does not observe precepts, does not give, does not cultivate, does not have wisdom, and does not attain supreme perfect enlightenment, this is impossible.
World-Honored One!
The buddhas, tathÄgatas, say that the nature of cause and effect is neither existent nor nonexistent. This meaning is also incorrect.

If the buddha-nature does not have the tree of anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, then how can it produce the tree of anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi?
For this reason, the meaning of cause and effect being neither existent nor nonexistent that you have spoken of, how is this meaning consistent?
At that time, the World-Honored One praised him, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
There are two kinds of people in the world who are extremely rare, like the udumbara flower:
One is one who does not engage in evil dharmas, and the other is one who is able to repent of their offenses. Such people are extremely rare.

The first is to create kindness, and the second is to remember kindness.
There are two other kinds of people:
The first is those who consult and accept new teachings, and the second is those who do not forget the old.
There are two other kinds of people:
The first is those who create new things, and the second is those who repair old things.
There are two other kinds of people:
The first is those who enjoy hearing the Dharma, and the second is those who enjoy speaking the Dharma.
There are two other kinds of people:
The first is those who are good at asking questions, and the second is those who are good at answering.
Those who are good at asking questions are you yourself;
Those who are good at answering are the TathÄgata.

Because of these good questions, one can turn the unsurpassed Dharma wheel, wither the great tree of the twelve links of dependent arising, cross the great river of birth and death beyond its limits, engage in battle with MÄra PÄpÄ«yÄn, and destroy the supreme banner established by PÄpÄ«yÄn.
Good man!
As I have said before:

Whether they obtain [these things] or not, their lifespans are fixed.
Why is this?
Because these people have cultivated three kinds of goodness over innumerable lifetimes, namely, superior, middling, and inferior.

Just as the people of Uttarakuru have a lifespan of a thousand years, if there are those who become ill, whether they encounter a good doctor, good medicine, and a nurse, or do not encounter them, they will all be cured.
Why is this?
Because their lifespans are fixed.
Good man!
As I have said:
'If a sick person encounters a good doctor, good medicine, and a nurse, their illness will be cured;
if they do not encounter them, they will not be cured.'
What does this mean?
Good man!
Such a person's lifespan is uncertain. Even if their life is not exhausted, there are nine causes and conditions that can shorten their lifespan.
What are the nine?

First, knowing that food is not suitable but still eating it; second, overeating; third, eating again before previous food is digested; fourth, not following the proper times for defecation and urination; fifth, not following the doctor's instructions when sick; sixth, not following the instructions of the nurse; seventh, forcibly suppressing and not vomiting; eighth, walking at night; because of walking at night, evil ghosts strike them; ninth, excessive sexual activity.
For these reasons, I say:
'If a sick person encounters medicine, the illness can be cured. If they do not encounter it, it cannot be cured.'
Good man!
As I said before:
'Whether they encounter it or not, both cannot be cured.'
What does this mean?
There are people whose life has ended, whether they encounter [a doctor] or not, they cannot be cured.
Why is it so?
Because their life has ended.
For this reason, I say:
'If a patient encounters medicine and treatment, or does not encounter them, they will all not be cured.'

Sentient beings are also like this. Those who give rise to the bodhi mind, whether they encounter good friends, buddhas, and bodhisattvas to receive and listen to the profound Dharma, or do not encounter them, will all attain [enlightenment].
Why is it so?
Because they are able to give rise to the bodhi mind, like the people of Uttarakuru who have a fixed lifespan.
As I have said:

'From stream-enterers to pratyekabuddhas, if they hear the profound Dharma spoken by good friends, buddhas, and bodhisattvas, they will give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment. If they do not encounter buddhas, bodhisattvas, and hear the teaching of the profound Dharma, they will not be able to give rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.'
Just as life is uncertain, there are nine causes and conditions that can lead to an untimely death, like that patient who encounters medicine and recovers from the illness;

Therefore, I say that encountering the Buddha, bodhisattvas, and hearing the profound Dharma can give rise to the resolve, but if one does not encounter it, one will not be able to give rise to it.
As I have previously said:
'If one encounters good friends, buddhas, bodhisattvas, and hears the profound Dharma, or if one does not encounter them, one will not be able to give rise to the resolve in either case.'
What does this mean?
Good man!

Because they have cut off wholesome dharmas.

Icchantika means faith;
Tika means incomplete.
Because they lack faith, they are called icchantikas.

Since they are not incomplete, how can it be cut off?

Since it is not complete, how can it be cut off?
E' means to advance,

Buddha-nature is not advancing, sentient beings are not complete.
Since it is not complete, how can it be cut off?
E' means to think,
ti means not to be complete.
Because one does not think and is not complete, it is called e'ti.
Buddha-nature is not thinking, sentient beings are not complete.
Since it is not complete, how can it be cut off?
E' means to be in samÄdhi,

Buddha-nature is neither impermanent, nor good, nor not good.
Why is this?
Good dharmas must be attained through skillful means, but buddha-nature is not attained through skillful means, therefore it is not good.
Why is it also called not not good?
Because it can attain the fruit of goodness, and the fruit of goodness is precisely supreme, perfect enlightenment.

But buddha-nature is not attained after birth, therefore it is not good.
Because one severs the good dharmas attained after birth, it is called icchantika.
Good son!
As you say:
If the icchantika has buddha-nature, why does it not prevent the sin of hell?

In the icchantika there is no buddha-nature.
Good son!
It is like a king who hears the sound of a lute, its sound clear and wonderful, and his mind becomes addicted to it, delighting in and cherishing it, unable to let go of it.
He then tells his great minister:
'From where does such a wonderful sound come out?'
The great minister replies:
'Such a wonderful sound comes from the lute.'
The king then says:
'Bring that sound here.'
At that time, the great minister then holds the lute in front of the king and says:
'Great king, you should know:
This is the sound.'
The king tells the lute:
'Make a sound, make a sound!'
But the lute still does not make a sound.
At that time, the great king immediately cuts its strings, but the sound still does not come out;

At that time, the great king became angry with the great minister:
How can you speak such false words?
The great minister said to the king:

It should be that with various conditions and skillful means, sound is then produced.
The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this, having no fixed abode, but can be seen due to skillful means;
Because it can be seen, one attains supreme, perfect enlightenment.

If those of wrong views believe in the existence of Buddha-nature, know that they will not go to the three evil destinies, and they are also not called those of wrong views.
Because they do not believe in themselves having Buddha-nature, they fall into the three evil destinies;
Because they fall into the three evil destinies, they are called those of wrong views.

As you have said:
'If milk has no nature of curd, it should not produce curd;

Foolish people make such statements, but the wise would never say such things.
Why is this?
Because of the absence of nature.

The Buddha-nature of sentient beings is also like this. It can be seen because of various conditions;

If it is to be accomplished by depending on various conditions, then it has no nature;

Because you taught them wrongly, you caused these two to give rise to evil thoughts.

The bodhisattva mahasattva, for the sake of the great nirvana and the twelve divisions of the canon, writes, recites, and explains them in detail, this is called the bodhisattva perfecting much learning.

Except for the twelve divisions of the scriptures, if one is able to uphold this subtle MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a SÅ«tra, to copy it, recite it, and explain it in detail, this is called a bodhisattva who is replete with much learning.
Except for this sÅ«tra, which is replete with the complete essence, if one is able to uphold a single four-line verse;

If there are good sons and good women who, for the MahÄparinirvÄá¹‡a, fully accomplish these five things, they can do what is difficult to do, endure what is difficult to endure, and give what is difficult to give.

If they hear that by giving away their country, city, wife, children, head, eyes, marrow, and brain to others, they can attain supreme, perfect enlightenment, they will give away all their possessions, their country, city, wife, children, head, eyes, marrow, and brain to others for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas. Although the bodhisattva may do what is difficult to do, he never thinks:
'This is what I have done.'

Good son!
It is like a parent who has only one child, loves it very much, and raises it with good clothes and delicious food, letting it have whatever it wants.
If the child gives rise to a disrespectful mind towards the parents, speaks evil words and insults them, because of their love, the parents do not become angry or resentful, and do not think:
'We provide this child with clothes and food.'
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this, regarding all sentient beings as their only child.
If a child falls ill, the parents also fall ill, seeking medicine and diligently treating the illness.
Once the child has recovered, they never think:
'I cured my child's illness and suffering.'
Bodhisattvas are also like this. Seeing sentient beings encountering the illness of afflictions, they give rise to a mind of loving-kindness and expound the Dharma for them.
Because of hearing the Dharma, the afflictions are severed.
Once the afflictions are severed, they never think:
'I have severed the afflictions for sentient beings.'
If they give rise to this thought, they will never be able to accomplish supreme, perfect enlightenment.
They only think:
'There is not a single sentient being for whom I expound the Dharma to sever afflictions.'
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not become angry or joyful towards sentient beings.
Why is this?
Because they are well able to cultivate the samÄdhi of emptiness.
If a bodhisattva cultivates the samÄdhi of emptiness, then toward whom should he give rise to anger or joy?
Good man!
It is like a mountain forest that is burned by a raging fire, cut down by people, or carried away by water. Should this forest give rise to anger or joy toward anyone?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. They have no anger or joy toward any sentient beings.
Why is this?
Because they cultivate the samÄdhi of emptiness.
At that time, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva Supreme Virtuous King of Universal Illumination addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
Are all dharmas inherently empty?
Are they empty because of emptiness?
If they are inherently empty, then one should not cultivate emptiness and then see emptiness.
How can the TathÄgata say that one sees emptiness by cultivating emptiness?
If the nature is inherently not empty, then even if one cultivates emptiness, one cannot make it empty.

The nature of all dharmas is originally self-empty.

Because the nature of all dharmas cannot be attained.

The nature of form cannot be attained.

The nature of form is not earth, water, fire, or wind, yet it is not apart from earth, water, fire, and wind;

it is neither existent nor nonexistent.

Because its nature cannot be attained, it is said to be empty.
